header.rec_loc: Campervan journey from Białka Tatrzańska to Tarnow, Poland – part 3.
header.topics: Eating before the gym, driving, time, gym (again), being English, gender issues, sexism, silence.
header.activity: Two friends talking about various topics (see 9 above) while driving in a campervan from Tarnow to Białka Tatrzańska, Poland – part 3.

speaker.occupation: unemployed/ Some part-time private TEFL teacher/ Semi-retired
Teacher of English as a foreign Language

you'll manage you'll manage yeah it will be in an hour and your metabolism'll still be racing away after your
yeah I hope so hope so hope so
it was awful it was really bad and I hadn't eaten enough breakfast and er I felt it
but he's nice he said it was okay he high-fived me

yeah yeah so it's you know er trying to eat erm
it's getting the balance isn't it?
eat enough but leaving enough time for you to start digesting

but I haven't driven for five years six years

and this is exactly what my mum did she learned to drive when she was in her twenties and then didn't drive until she was forty something
and she had to have lessons
and I imagine that's what's gonna happen to me er it doesn't help that I'm never in the country erm or never you know
er I mean I wouldn't wanna drive abroad anyway
so actually you could just forget about that now forget about the anxiety and just say

what? to drive to go places?
or just to sort of drive myself around the town
see my friends or whatever erm
I've gotta say Poland isn't easy

erm it is if you think erm if you kind of get in your head nobody's thinking anything about me nobody's judging me and once you get that in your head you're fine you can get on and drive but but there is like I was saying to you before you expect it on motorways you pull out to overtake at the last possible minute and you get in again at the l
at the s the first available opportunity so you're kind of cutting vehicles up as you're pulling in and you're almost sometimes pulling out in front of people bbut that is expected
so you know I kind of feel sometimes I'm driving like a dickhead but that's
it's expected that's the culture that's the custom so really in just being in Rome and doing as the Romans do but it is pretty anxiety-inducing sometimes
so no probably not the best country

I wouldn't yeah I wouldn't drive abroad erm anywhere er but I really want to

waving at you it's just really nice and they had a wooden Rudolph and his sleigh as well that was about ten feet from left to right and er yeah that was all lit up it was really nice
right now we're through those lights we might

your obsession with time it doesn't exist there's nothing to claw back

I'm kind of at the stage in life now as well where if I'm running late and I say to someone oh I'm sorry running late if I think I'm gonna be there at five past I'll message and say oh I'll see you about quarter past and then I just really relax and don't drive like a dickhead
and the person the other end isn't anxiously looking out of the window or whatever if people do that sort of thing I don't know
erm yeah and it and I kind of think well late is late so whether it's five minutes or fifteen minutes it's still late so
you might as well just be late in a relaxed kind of a way
I can't er I hate being late
rush around like an idiot and get there at five past or three minutes past and still be late
but be all anxious and stressed?
it depends who er or what I'm doing
what who I'm meeting I suppose but you know in the mornings I hate rushing

er er er have a shower

that's good yeah I m think you're doing magnificently you really seem to be feeling on a buzz and
that's where we're going oh no it's not
oh shit I forgot my swimming goggles ah
yeah I g I've not got any here I couldn't find any when I was leaving England
oh what's the limit here? I'm just going extra slow cos of that speed camera everyone else going extra slow okay erm
yeah no I have got some here

but actually no I don't really like swimming that much I used to go I used to go a lot it's funny in different phases that you have in life when my partner was really sick with cancer and I was still going to work every day rather than come home faff about and go to the gym of an evening

I used to bunk off work quite a bit actually I used to say I'm going to this shop in this part of the country and maybe I would go but maybe I'd leave an hour before I was really meant to or they thought I was
and then I'd go to the gym in on the way home and go for a swim erm or go and run cos I was running at that point before my knees completely gave up

and yeah I found it really necessary to have that time and that space and when m I was in England with my mum and her cancer and going between her flat and the hospice a lot I was forever getting Groupon deals for local gyms to go and run
and it just seemed so necessary to have that outlet for myself and that time that was selfish time
and you know it's so good for you too
mm it's all them dolphins innit?
endorphins and I know people sort of say oh it's so cathartic it's therapeutic you know you get out all of your anger and stress and you think well I don't really know if I agree with that but
I agree with you're doing something on a regular basis in which you are trying to improve you know
and over time you will because that's how that's how h the the human body works
you know you'll be able to go faster or lift something else up and that is I think good for your mind
yeah that's how I sort of er see it I don't really like erm competition necessarily with other people cos I'm not very good and I w don't usually win anything
no I just like to go because it feels good
and I like I used to get to that point with running where I felt I could run forever
and it just felt so good
I used to only do I used to do five K
so three miles in about thirty-eight minutes
erm which is incredibly slow but I didn't care
yeah if you like it then
yeah I th I think oh shit I thought I was gonna stall then erm yeah I think I'm just generally a slow laid-back take it easy kind of a person
and even in my movement and my doeyness I'm it's very unusual I just don't get that

s oh and where's the cheese?
a winning combination gets a lot of passing trade

so yeah I just it's all I don't get that with a workout I I get a buzz and I get high from it but in a still in a chilled out kind of a way
just in a f almost a floaty kind of a way yeah yeah spin classes I love spin bike classes
but I mean in my arse end of nowhere gym there were two types of instructor it's usually the young men erm who every track whether it's a hill track or a sprint track is bloody fast
and it was always a faster faster faster and I used to think fuck off fuck off fuck off
I'll go at my own speed and I used to get a bit stubborn then and

go really slow and not enjoy it and then it was usually women erm not always older women but often older women running the spin classes that lull you into a false sense of security with making sure you warm through properly at the beginning you might have a running track erm rather than sprint
and you just kind of warm into it gradually and within about twenty minutes I'd be working incredibly hard and I'd be knackered
and I'd think how did you get me to do that? without you know screaming and shouting and doing all of that
I used to sort of I used to go spinning erm when I was at uni and I'd look at the clock and it'd be like quarter past I'd be like fuck I've got to do this for another thirty minutes? I'm gonna die
I'm not gonna make it and we yeah when I used to go to the gym and do erm you know all these conditioning classes or whatever
and there was this trainer called this was in last year and she was brutal she was the fittest strongest woman I've ever seen

you know l huge muscles and really kind of great body erm and I've spoken to her about her body once and she said that she hated it and she hated that she she always wanted to wear a jacket or cover her arms or

cos people are so slim erm but no good for her it's like well I'd do anything to sort of well I am doing some things to get that sort of body

you strike me more a lover than a fighter

you want to be a meathead

and it was packed I think they'd the women had sent men
and it was like men and their sons as well
er to the gym just to get them out of the house and obviously I wasn't gonna be cooking and preparing a family meal so I was there

I think this'll be really good for me in terms of getting stuff out toxins and that

oh yeah yeah definitely and steam's incredibly good for that I am good friends with the a woman who used to work in one of the gyms that my Northern Ireland card erm worked for and and so actually I think I had a cold that wasn't shifting or something like that so I was wanting to steam it out and so I'd just send her a text and she would ring the gym and get them to change the menthol thing that they put through the pipe
so it's all nice and really strong and I'd say I'll be down about three and then by the time I got there it's really pumping out the menthol eucalyptus that was perfect

really perfect no I miss her she's a really nice woman she had a campervan as well erm but she's funny because we're we're both quite similar in a way we've been on campervan adventures but we've both taken our own vans and followed each other
it's like she likes her space and I like my space
and I suppose things can get a little bit intimate in a campervan
and er you know I know her well enough to share a small bed with her it wouldn't be a problem erm but yeah I suppose you just yeah also I like my van
she likes her van so yeah creature comforts

yeah that was lovely we had a fabulous trip around actually in erm in Ireland and we were looking for a stone circle and a lot of places in Ireland you can read about them but you can't find them there's

no no there are no signposts so I r it was Easter I think it might even've been Easter Sunday driving in rural and just I stopped and asked somebody do you know where these standing stones are? and they pointed me to the correct field but looked a bit confused and it was only afterwards that said you know it's Easter Sunday? and they'd just come out of chapel having had you know one of the most holy masses of the year
and you you pagan are asking where the stones are the standing stones
so but I could get away with a lot being English that she couldn't being Irish so
I wouldn't you know being English I wouldn't want to be from anywhere else
and it can close them a bit as well sometimes

yeah I had a guy I worked with in Northern Ireland erm part of my role was to help a charitable organisation be more profitable and I'd only just arrived and said hi how are you? to everybody and this older guy came up to me and said and you can just fuck off because I was English
yeah in when I lived in Scotland and worked in Scotland they erm did say stuff to me
said someone once called me a wee English tart
well you are correct on all counts
you know and stuff like that it was

yeah yeah friendly abuse as well
get back over your own side
the troubles and yeah and I worked for a Catholic organisation and lived in a Catholic community
so even not being a Christian I was still the Prod
and then at work they used to joke sometimes to say right cultural diversity oi Prod girl what do you think to this? and then ask me a question and get my view on whatever so
yeah I suppose I could of perceived it as workplace bullying but
instead I'd quite often tell them to fuck off so it was fine
I'm no my temperature's fine I'm just
this window's going a bit steamy
steamy you've got your own erm yellow and blue thing down there

give it a wipe in fact poor she's filthy so she is she really needs a bloody good clean erm I dunno there's just something about the design of this particular model of Volkswagen where and actually I m had a Honda Accord that was just the same that you got shite on the outside of the windows so you can't see out your mirror
you'd think well you'd think they'd've tested that in the aerodynamic tunnel thing at the testy place to
I don't know put some mud through it on occasion to see where it ends up
it's like a little winter wonderland here I think the difference between here and is there is a lot more snow stuck to the trees
yeah it looks great doesn't it?
what time was leaving as erm after she'd been to yours?
yeah I think she'd called at mine a little bit before nine
picked up her helmet and goggles and came away

I wonder though I see a lot of this with Polish women in particular and I suppose I was quite like that myself and I do wonder if it's a female thing is having to be ten times better than anybody else to get the same recognition that an average man gets
and whether there's any truth in that or whether that's just a perception
I don't know and it was weird being magnificent and being the best in England
at erm you know business things and making shed loads of money and taking unprofitable shops and making them profitable and blah blah blah and doing really great and then
going over to Northern Ireland I'm back in a
back in a I dunno you think England's a patriarchy move to Northern Ireland mate bloody hell
I was working with committees of sort of sixty to ninety-year-old Catholic men who didn't have a fucking clue about business and were trying to tell me what they wanted
I think with teaching though it's slightly different in that it is erm a female-dominated industry
and directors of schools and headmistresses and English er nnot English er are women
er I used to hate and and giving me sort of advice on how to teach
I'd be like no really shut up really don't have any any need
and don't you have more experience than and ?
yeah I suppose teaching has tended to be a profession that's pretty piss poor paid as well
apart from in a lot of northern European countries

and once they have so many years in the role they get extra tax breaks and big pensions and things like that it's very well respected I think they get a lot more shit from the students than
erm you know perhaps further northern countries

nasty about the car that it's trying to get into the boot of so as a driver you just kind of need to accept that people are gonna drive right up your arse and that it's nothing personal it's like being in a car with with with erm
and they all drive like that and they're
they're not swearing at the car in front they're just going about their business
it's just what they do erm but as a driver that's more accustomed to having much more space
between vehicles erm you can take it a bit personally if you don't know that's what I meant about if you do decide to do some driving lessons
